Aerial Robotics Kharagpur shared NASA Jet Propulsion Laboratory's post. From Mission Control to Times Square, relive the #MarsLanding celebrations that erupted when NASA InSight touched down on the Red Planet. https://go.nasa.gov/2P6OFf0

For most people, the sky is the limit, but for us, the sky is our home.

Join us tomorrow (30th Jan) in Kalidas auditorium at 6 pm for our introductory seminar.

More details at: https://www.facebook.com/events/349847128949659/

For the first time in IIT Kharagpur, we are excited to present Guest Lecture by scientist from the organization that is developing Mars Helicopter which would be launched along with the M2020 rover in 2020. 

Here we share with you the concept video made by NASA, JPL. Come join us to know more in the event.

For more details, visit: https://www.facebook.com/events/349847128949659/

Time to go full throttle!

We welcome everyone to two exciting events:

1)  We are organizing a guest lecture by Shreyansh Daftry from NASA, Jet Propulsion Laboratory. 6pm onwards.

Followed by:

2) Introductory Seminar of Aerial Robotics Lab (ARK) for freshers.

Venue: Kalidas Auditorium.

Found a long lost medical kit, a fully functional tablet and a broken half chair that we still don't feel like discarding for some reason.
Maintaining an inventory is our way of feeling Christmas!

message:
Great move by DGCA to allow and regulate the flights of unmanned aircrafts.
More details can be find in: https://digitalsky.dgca.gov.in/

This would enforce safety while enabling legal flights and commercialization.

Before every long range flight tests, we go through our basic checklist to ensure all systems are "go" for flight.

This pic shows a successful rock solid position hold using px4 firmware and based on GPS. (It wouldn't drift if not commanded, the reason we are able to stand close to it while flying).

We are preparing for long range flights over KGP and so people on campus might be able to spot us testing in TSC 🙂 from tomorrow onwards.

#unfilteredARK

Same day, but a year ago. Each year, we stay back at KGP for 15 days out of the 30 days of winter vacation to work on the projects.

Our laboratory setup has changed and so have our projects in a year. What remains constant is the team and the positive zeal to move forward.
#unfilteredARK

Let us take you all behind the scenes to witness our research and projects in the making. 

We are excited to share our enthusiasm with new series of posts with the tag .
#unfilteredARK

This pic: We are gearing up for long range autonomous flights with better hardware. Our team (Abhinav Ukey, Zeeshan Aejaz, Aryan Jaiswal) finished installing the cover which will prevent barometric fluctuations due to wind, along with long range telemetry.

Manash Pratim Das shared a post to Aerial Robotics Kharagpur's timeline. The first test flight of Falcon Heavy is targeted for Tuesday, February 6th at 1:30 PM ET from Launch Complex 39A at Kennedy Space Center in Florida. When Falcon Heavy lifts off, it will be the most powerful operational rocket in the world by a factor of two. For this test flight, Falcon Heavy’s side cores are flight-proven—both previously supported independent Falcon 9 missions in 2016. instagram.com/p/Be1jFT2lQ0W

"For once you have tasted flight you will walk the earth with your eyes turned skywards, for there you have been and there you will long to return. "
Embarking on a journey of thrill and exploration, Aerial Robotics Kharagpur invites all first and second year robotics enthusiasts to join us in the Introductory Seminar.
February 23rd | Kalidas Auditorium | 6 PM
Fill out the form here to register yourself: https://quadrotor-iitkgp.github.io/recruit and tinyurl.com/SwarmSelections2017
